newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: LUGE-GERMANY'S ERDMANN WINS THIRD WORLD GOLD.
newsitem.headline: LUGE-GERMANY'S ERDMANN WINS THIRD WORLD GOLD.

text.p: German Susi Erdmann won her third luge world championship gold medal on Saturday, edging out compatriot and title-holder Jana Bode by 45 hundredths of a second.

Erdmann, who also triumphed at the 1989 and 1991 world championships, became the first women to clock a time below the 40 seconds mark on the Igls track which hosted the 1964 and 1976 Olympic luge events.

Erdmann was the first to smash the women's course record at Igls when she posted a fastest first run time of 39.945. In the second leg, she clocked the second best time of 39.986 for a winning aggregate of one minute 19.931 seconds.
"I am so happy that I managed to win a gold again after such a long time," said Erdmann, the 1992 European champion.
"Now my goal is to do well in Nagano. At the (1998) Olympics I definately want to make a medal," she added.
Austria's 1992 Olympic champion Angelika Neuner clinched bronze in 1:19.988 while her compatriots Tobias and Markus Schiegl successfully defended their title in the doubles.
The Schiegl cousins, who on Friday helped Austria win the team competition, clocked a winning total time of 1:19.732 for their fourth world championship gold medal.
The German pairings of Stefan Krausse/Jan Behrendt (1:19.777) and Steffen Skel/Steffen Woeller (1:19.809) took silver and bronze respectively.
"I never dreamed we would be able to win four medals today," said delighted German coach Thomas Schwab.
Germany placed five in the top seven in the women's event -- in which 41 athletes from 15 countries participated -- with Sylke Otto fourth, Barbara Niedernhuber sixth and Sylke Kraushaar seventh.
